A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal arches, clefts and pouches

Pharyngeal arches
  • Pharyngeal arches are key structures in head and neck development, appearing in the fourth and fifth weeks as mesenchymal tissue bars.
  • They resemble gills but do not function as such in humans.
  • Pharyngeal arches are divided by pharyngeal clefts on the outside and pharyngeal pouches on the inside.
  • Pharyngeal pouches develop as outpocketings from the lateral walls of the pharynx and do not connect to the exterior, playing crucial roles in organ development.
  • Each arch incorporates neural crest cells essential for forming facial skeleton components, while mesoderm differentiates into facial and neck musculature.
  • Each arch has its own cranial nerve and artery.

Pharyngeal Pouches
  • Four Pairs (fifth is rudimentary)
  • First Pouch: Forms the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube, contributing to the tympanic membrane.
  • Second Pouch: Develops into palatine tonsils; remnants persist as the tonsillar fossa.
  • Third Pouch: Dorsal wing becomes the inferior parathyroid gland; ventral wing forms the thymus, migrating to the thorax.
  • Fourth Pouch: Dorsal region forms the superior parathyroid gland; ventral region becomes the ultimobranchial body, integrating into the thyroid.

Pharyngeal Clefts
  • Five-week-old Embryo: Four clefts are present.
  • First Cleft: Does not form the external auditory meatus (EAM); instead, the EAM arises from surface ectoderm invagination. It eventually disappears due to overgrowth by the second arch.
  • Second, Third, and Fourth Clefts: Overgrown by the second arch, they lose exterior contact and may temporarily form the cervical sinus, which ultimately disappears.

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of pterygium?

options.label: C
options.text: The parts of a pterygium are the head, neck and body

questions.explanation:
Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn
 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflamed pterygium
  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

Match the following Wullstein's Classification Procedure/other name A. Type II B. Type III C. Type IV D. Type V 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty 2. Graft placed over the incus 3. Cavum minor 4. Columella tympanoplasty
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I

Myringoplasty: Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane using a graft.

Type II

Graft placed on incus or remaining malleus with an eroded malleus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Type III

Graft placed directly on stapes head in absence of malleus and incus (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

Type IV

Graft placed between oval and round windows, exposing stapes footplate (cavum minor), allowing sound to act directly on footplate.

Type V

Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the horizontal semicircular canal, covering it with a graft when the stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functional.

Aspect

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features

Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.

A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high arched palate, and impaired hearing. His tympanogram is given below. What would be the most appropriate management for him?
questions.explanation:
Tympanogram Type

Characteristics

Indication

Type A

Normal peak

Normal middle ear function

Type As

Shallow peak

Ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis)

Type Ad

Deep peak

Ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane

Type B

Flat, no peak

Middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane

Type C

Peak at negative pressure

Eustachian tube dysfunction, middle ear negative pressure

Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube

Allergy

Unresolved otitis media

Viral infections
  • Adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Chronic tonsillitis: Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours: Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media.
  • Palatal defects: e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis.
  • Down's syndrome.

Seasonal or perennial allergies obstruct the Eustachian tube and increase middle ear mucosal secretions.

Inadequate antibiotic therapy can lead to persistent, low-grade infection, stimulating more mucous production and increasing goblet cells.


Adenoviruses and rhinoviruses can invade the middle ear mucosa, leading to increased secretory activity.

Procedure

Details

Myringotomy and Aspiration of Fluid

An incision in the tympanic membrane to aspirate fluid; thick mucus may require saline or mucolytic agents like chymotrypsin solution.

Grommet Insertion

If fluid recurs after myringotomy and aspiration, a grommet is inserted for continued middle ear aeration; remains in place for weeks or months.

Tympanotomy or Cortical Mastoidectomy

Required for removing loculated thick fluid or other pathologies like cholesterol granuloma.

Surgical Treatment of Causative Factor

Procedures like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and/or maxillary antra washout may be needed, typically performed during myringotomy.

Cause

Symptoms

Treatment

Exposure to extreme cold (-2.5ºC), causing tissue freezing and blood supply obstruction

Blue-black discoloration of fingers, toes, nose, ears, face.

  • Severe cases: paresthesia, stiffness, necrosis, gangrene, edema, blisters.
  • Rewarming:
    • For superficial frostbite (frostnip): Firm steady pressure is applied with a warm hand (without rubbing), by placing fingers in the armpits and for the feet, by covering with dry socks

  • Pressure or friction is avoided
  • Anti-infective measures: Tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics for deep infection

questions.text: Consider the following actions under AMTSL (Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor). Arrange them in the correct order: Uterine massage Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 IU) Exclude the presence of another fetus Controlled cord traction
questions.explanation:
1. Injecting Uterotonics

Inject uterotonic (e.g., Oxytocin 10 IU) within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after the delivery of the anterior shoulder. (Statement 2)
  • Most important step in AMTSL.
  • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV infusion) is the preferred uterotonic.
  • Not recommended by WHO: carboprost.
  • Administer within 1-3 minutes of delivery.

2. Delayed Cord Clamping

Delay cord clamping for at least 1 minute after birth.
  • About 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus.
  • Helps prevent fetal anemia by allowing time for placental blood flow to transfer to the baby.

3. Delivery of Placenta by Controlled Cord Traction

Perform controlled cord traction using the modified Brandt-Andrews technique. (Statement 4)
  • Controlled cord traction should be done after administering uterotonics.
  • Technique: apply gentle downward traction to the cord while counter-traction on the uterine fundus facilitates placental delivery.

4. Intermittent Assessment of Uterine Tone

Assess uterine tone intermittently to ensure uterine contraction is maintained.
  • Done every 15 minutes for 2 hours post-delivery.
  • Only in settings where skilled birth attendants are available.
  • Uterus is pushed upwards and backward while cord traction is downward and forward.

5. Uterine Massage (Optional)

Perform uterine massage only if uterine atony is suspected or after placental delivery. (Statement 1)
  • Not recommended as a routine intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin).
  • Now an optional component of AMTSL in cases of uterine atony or PPH management.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for vulval cancer except:
questions.explanation:
Chronic Vulval Irritation

Persistent irritation or inflammation (e.g., from infections or allergies) can cause cellular changes, increasing cancer risk.

Immunosuppressive Conditions

HIV, pregnancy, and other immunosuppressive conditions lower immune surveillance, increasing cancer risk.

Smoking (Option C ruled out)

A carcinogen that impairs immune function, significantly increasing the risk of vulval and other cancers.

Condyloma (Anogenital Warts) (Option D ruled out)

HPV infection (serotypes 16, 18) causes condyloma and is strongly linked to vulval cancer.

Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs)

HPV (serotypes 16, 18) is the main STD linked to vulval cancer, leading to persistent infections and cellular changes.

Vulval Dystrophies (Option A ruled out)

Chronic conditions like lichen sclerosus and lichen planus cause tissue changes that increase malignancy risk.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks + 5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management?

options.text: Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete

options.label: D
options.text: Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation

  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management

  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management

  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation.

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  1. HELLP syndrome
  2. Pulmonary edema
  3. Eclampsia
  4. Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  5. Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  6. Worsening renal function
  7. Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  8. Visual disturbances
  9. Motor deficits
  10. Altered sensorium
  11. Stroke
  12. Myocardial infarction
  1. Abnormal fetal testing
  2. Fetal death
  3. Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  4. Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management

  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

questions.text: What can be said about this graph?

options.label: B
options.text: The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia.

options.label: D
options.text: This is a uterine contraction graph.

questions.correct_answer: A. This is a non-stress test.
questions.explanation:
1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability:
  • Normal: 110-160 bpm
  • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm.
  • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm.
  • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next.
  • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal).

3. Accelerations
  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.

4. Decelerations

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
  • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression.
  • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency.

5. Fetal Movements
  • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress.

Interpretation:
  • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function.
  • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

questions.correct_answer: C. Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months
questions.explanation:
Category

Definition

Treatment

Platinum-sensitive

Ovarian cancer that recurs more than 6 months after completing platinum-based chemotherapy.

Treated with platinum-based therapies such as carboplatin, paclitaxel, or gemcitabine.

Platinum-resistant

Ovarian cancer that relapses within 6 months of primary platinum-based chemotherapy. (Options A, B and D ruled out)

Treated with palliative, non-platinum chemotherapy. Drugs such as Bevacizumab in combination with paclitaxel, doxorubicin, or topotecan.

Platinum-refractory

Ovarian cancer that progresses during primary chemotherapy, often with a worse prognosis.

Treatment options are limited; may include alternative chemotherapy agents or clinical trials.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost

options.label: B
options.text: Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth

options.label: C
options.text: PPH is the loss of 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Causes include retained placenta and uterine atony

questions.correct_answer: A. Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost
questions.explanation:
Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors increasing risk

Uterine Atony (Most common)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use.
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Intrauterine device (IUD)

  • Massive haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Aortic injuries
  • Tracheobronchial injuries
  • Myocardial contusion
  • Rupture of the diaphragm
  • Oesophageal injuries
  • Pulmonary contusion

Tension Pneumothorax

 

Definition

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology

• It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.

• ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology

• Penetrating chest trauma.

• Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.

• Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation), and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features

• Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.

• Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.

• Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.

• Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management

• Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle". 

• Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.

• Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

What preoperative intervention can be administered to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a 32-year-old female patient diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting with eye symptoms and an enlarged thyroid, who is scheduled to undergo a total thyroidectomy?
questions.explanation:
Grave’s Disease

Pathogenesis

  • An autoimmune disorder characterised by the production of long-acting thyroid stimulator (LATS) or thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies against the TSH receptor, which results in Hyperthyroidism.
  • Increased beta-receptor expression results in sympathetic stimulation (Tachycardia, Fine tremors, Sweating).

Characteristic Features
  • Thyrotoxicosis (Symptoms of Hyperthyroidism)
  • Ophthalmopathy (Exophthalmos): Accumulation of areolar tissue behind the eye.
  • Pretibial Myxedema
  • Gynaecomastia

Diagnosis
  • Clinical: Presence of eye signs in hyperthyroid patients.
  • Confirmatory Test: Detection of thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies.

Eye Signs
  • Stellwag's Sign: Reduced blink rate or incomplete blinking.
  • Dalrymple’s Sign: Visible upper sclera with lid retraction
  • Von Graefe's Sign: Lid lag on down gaze
  • Joffroy's Sign: Absence of Forehead wrinkling on Upgaze
  • Moebius Sign: Loss of Accommodation

Management

Medical management:

  • Propranolol (provide symptomatic relief)
  • Antithyroid drugs like Propylthiouracil (DOC in 1st trimester), Methimazole, and Carbimazole (Can be given in 2n and 3rd trimesters)

Surgical Intervention: Total Thyroidectomy is the treatment of choice, especially when other methods fail or are contraindicated (Lugol’s iodine is used for the pre-operative preparation).

  • Adults with Goiter are managed by drugs followed by surgery.
  • Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Ablation:
    • Indications: Elderly patients with surgical comorbidities or recurrence after surgery.
    • Contraindications: Pregnancy, Lactation, Patient with eye signs (worsens Ophthalmopathy)

questions.text: The correct sequence of events during vomiting are? 1. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter 2. Strong contractions in the stomach 3. Inspiration against a closed glottis 4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter 5. Relaxation of upper esophageal sphincter 6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

1. Relaxation of LES

LES relaxes to allow stomach contents to move into the esophagus.

2. Strong Contractions in Stomach

Abdominal and diaphragm muscles contract to propel stomach contents upward.

3. Inspiration Against Closed Glottis

Deep breath with glottis closed creates negative pressure for expulsion.

4. Relaxation of UES

UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit the mouth.

5. Reverse Peristalsis in Small Intestine

Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach.

6. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter

In severe vomiting, pyloric sphincter relaxes, aiding in expulsion.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of?
questions.explanation:
Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

• Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

• Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

 

Indications

Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localised to the head of the pancreas. 

Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management. 

Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct (distal cholangiocarcinoma), and ampulla of Vater. (Option C)

Procedure Steps

Tumor Assessment: Explore the abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread. 

Resection: Remove the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection. 

Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction

Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect the remaining pancreas to the jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to the jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles

Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing. 

Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications

• Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues. 

• Delayed Gastric Emptying

• Bleeding, wound infection

• Reoperation, increased mortality 

• Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple, the pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularisation of the spleen.

questions.text: Severe, intractable pain in advanced rectum cancers is due to:
questions.explanation:
Technique

Indications

Local Excision

Suitable for early-stage cancers (T1 and selected T2) with good prognostic factors; preserves rectum and anal sphincter, minimizing bowel function impact.

Anterior Resection

Preferred for most cancers in the middle and lower rectum; involves removing affected rectal parts and reconnecting the colon to the remaining rectum.

Abdominoperineal Excision (APR)

Reserved for low-lying, extensive tumours unsuitable for sphincter-saving; involves removing rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues, creating a permanent colostomy.

Hartmann's Procedure

Involves removing the rectum and creating a temporary colostomy, suitable for elderly or frail patients.

questions.text: Where is the site of the lesion that leads to the occurrence of hemiballismus in a patient displaying forceful, flinging movements?
questions.explanation:

Lesion in subthalamic nucleus (STN)

Huntington’s Disease (HD)

Lesions in the caudate nucleus

Sydenham's chorea

Rheumatic heart disease

Condition

Description

Tremor

Rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions.

Dystonia

Involuntary, patterned, sustained, or repeated muscle contractions often associated with twisting movements and abnormal posture.

Athetosis

Slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect the arms and hands (this represents a form of dystonia with increased mobility).

Chorea

Rapid, semipurposeful, graceful, dance like non patterned involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups. When the movements are of large amplitude and predominant proximal distribution, the term ballism is used.

Ballismus

Violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body

Myoclonus

Sudden, brief (<100 ms), jerklike, arrhythmic muscle twitches.

Tic

Brief, repeated, stereotyped muscle contractions that can often be suppressed for a short time. These can be simple and involve a single muscle group or complex and affect a range of motor activities.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
West Syndrome

Age group

Typically occurs between 2 and 12 months of age.

Genetics

ARX Gene Mutations: In males, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.

Types
  • Cryptogenic (Unknown Etiology): Normal development before onset.
  • Symptomatic: Associated with developmental delays due to perinatal issues, brain malformations, metabolic disorders, or other causes.

Clinical Features
  • Infantile Epileptic Spasms: Clusters of spasms occurring mainly during drowsiness or upon waking.
  • Developmental Regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: A chaotic, high-voltage background with multifocal spikes.

Management

First-Line Treatment: Hormonal therapy, primarily ACTH (80 mg/mL)

  • Dosage: 150 units/m² daily (75 units/m² twice daily) for 2 weeks, then taper gradually.
  • Monitoring: EEGs at 1, 2, and 4 weeks to assess response.
  • Early intervention is crucial, as a delay beyond 3 weeks can worsen the prognosis.

Alternative Treatments
  • Oral Prednisolone: Lower-cost alternative (Less effective)
  • Vigabatrin: Used as a first-line agent in West syndrome associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or second-line if hormonal therapy fails. Side effects include retinal toxicity.
  • Ketogenic Diet: Considered a third-line therapy.
  • Other Medications: Valproate, benzodiazepines (nitrazepam, clonazepam), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, pyridoxine, and IVIG. These drugs can help reduce seizure frequency and severity but are not uniformly effective and may be used alongside ACTH or vigabatrin in cases with incomplete response.

Side Effects and Precautions
  • Side Effects of Hormonal Therapy: Hypertension, electrolyte imbalance, infections, hyperglycemia, and gastric ulcers.
  • Vaccination: Live vaccines are contraindicated, and other vaccines may be ineffective during and shortly after hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child?
questions.explanation:
Scarlet Fever

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis is associated with a characteristic rash caused due to a pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin) produced by GAS in individuals lacking antitoxin antibodies.

Caused By

Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Incidence and Virulence

Less common and less virulent now compared to the past, with incidence depending on toxin strains and the population immunity.

Clinical Features
  • Rash appears within 24-48 hours, starting around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities.
  • Rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption causing bright-red discoloration, which blanches on pressure.
  • Rash is accentuated in the creases of the elbow, axilla, and groin (Pastia lines) and gives the skin a goose-pimple appearance.
  • Erythematous cheeks with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash fades, followed by desquamation starting on the face and progressing downward.
  • Desquamation may occur around fingernails, palms, and soles.
  • Tongue is coated with swollen papillae, which later give a "strawberry tongue" appearance after desquamation.
  • Pharyngitis.

Diagnosis
  • Classic scarlet fever is typically straightforward to diagnose.
  • A history of recent exposure to GAS is helpful.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying GAS in the pharynx.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergy: Oral cephalosporins, clindamycin, Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin) for 10 days or azalide (azithromycin) for 5 days.
  • Injection: Benzathine penicillin G single dose intramuscular injection for those unlikely to complete oral therapy.

Complication

  • Suppurative Complications:
    • Cervical lymphadenitis
    • Peritonsillar abscess
    • Retropharyngeal abscess
    • Otitis media
    • Mastoiditis
    • Sinusitis
    • Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pneumonia
  • Nonsuppurative Complications:
    • Acute rheumatic fever
    • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Image

Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? It is called Shelter's tape. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.explanation:
Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)

Definition
  • MUAC is a vital measurement used primarily to assess the nutritional status of children aged 6 months to 5 years.
  • Quick and effective screening tool.
  • In infants under 6 months old, the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is not utilized as a measurement criterion. (G88)

Procedure
  • Ensure the child is standing straight with their left arm free of clothing. The arm should be bent at a right angle.
  • Measure the distance between the tip of the shoulder (acromion) and the tip of the elbow (olecranon). Mark the midpoint on the upper arm.
  • The child's arm should hang relaxed by their side, with the palm facing the thigh.
  • Use a MUAC tape to wrap around the marked midpoint of the arm. The tape should be snug but not tight enough to pinch the skin.
  • Record the measurement at the zero mark of the tape.

Shakir’s Tape

Shakir's tape (1) is a specific type of MUAC measuring tape designed for use in assessing malnutrition. (2)

Used by frontline field workers for nutritional screening of malnourished children. (4)

It is typically three colour-coded to facilitate easy interpretation of nutritional status. The tape is marked with different zones that correspond to various levels of malnutrition:

  • Red Zone: Indicates severe malnutrition (MUAC < 11.5 cm).
  • Yellow Zone: Indicates moderate malnutrition (MUAC between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm).
  • Green Zone: Indicates healthy nutritional status (MUAC > 12.5 cm) (3)

 

SHAKIR’S TAPE

A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/µL, the majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 70 mg/dL (blood glucose level - 300 mg/dL). How will you manage the index case?
questions.explanation:
Bacterial meningitis in neonates and children

Common Causes by Age Group

Neonates

Pre-school Children

Older Children
  • Escherichia coli (gram-negative bacilli)
  • Group B streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical Features
  • Lethargy
  • Fever
  • Hypothermia
  • Seizure
  • Headache
  • Stiff neck
  • Irritability
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting

Diagnosis

Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis):

  • CSF Appearance: Cloudy or purulent
  • CSF Pressure: Elevated
  • WBC Count: Elevated (1000-5000 cells/µL)
  • Predominant Cells: Neutrophils
  • Protein: Elevated (>100 mg/dL)
  • Glucose: Low (<40 mg/dL or <40% of blood glucose)
  • Gram Stain: Positive for bacteria

Treatment
  • Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • Third generation cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) along with vancomycin x 10 to 14 days
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Inj. Dexamethasone started 1-2 hr before antibiotics and continued for 48 hrs - Prevents cytokine mediated CNS injury.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Complications

Hearing loss (common with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae), seizures, memory impairment, decreased intellectual function, hydrocephalus, sepsis, and risk of death

A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient? Diazepam Thiamine Naltrexone Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold.

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioral approaches are recommended.

questions.text: A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. Which of the following risks is increased in the newborn? Low APGAR score ADHD Persistent pulmonary hypertension Delayed developmental milestones
questions.explanation:
SSRIs in Pregnancy

Fetal outcomes
  • SSRIs generally do not increase the risk of major congenital malformations, except for paroxetine, which is associated with increased heart defect risks when taken during the first trimester.
  • Late pregnancy SSRI use can lead to Poor Neonatal Adaptation Syndrome (PNAS), which includes irritability, poor muscle tone, sleep problems, crying, irritability, hypoglycemia, and seizures.
  • Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) is a rare but serious risk.
  • Low APGAR score
  • There is an increased risk of ADHD and autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
  • Delayed Developmental Milestones

Maternal outcomes
  • It may impair platelet function and myometrial contractions, disrupting normal hemostasis and vasoconstriction, which can increase the risk of Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • They can influence serotonin levels and inhibit nitric oxide synthesis, leading to vascular changes that elevate the risk of pre-eclampsia.
  • SSRIs may worsen insulin resistance, increasing the risk of GDM during pregnancy.
  • Minimal amounts of SSRIs are present in breast milk, with no reported harmful effects in breastfed babies.

Safer SSRIs in Pregnancy
  • Citalopram,
  • Sertraline,
  • Escitalopram,
  • Fluoxetine.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with the lesion given in the image below. He also mentions experiencing sensations like a spider crawling in the area of the lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Etiology

Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) from latency in sensory ganglia.

Risk Factors

Immunosuppression, aging (>50 years), stress, malignancy, chronic diseases (diabetes).

Clinical Features

Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base along a single dermatome (usually thoracic, lumbar, or trigeminal).

Prodromal Symptoms

Burning, tingling, paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), fever, malaise before rash appears.

Complications

Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN), bacterial superinfection, ophthalmic zoster (if V1 of trigeminal nerve is involved).

Diagnosis

Clinical; Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells), PCR for VZV in doubtful cases.

Treatment

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) within 72 hours, analgesics, corticosteroids (if severe pain).

Prevention

Zoster vaccine for elderly and immunocompromised individuals.

Clinical features

  • Mild fever with diarrhoea
  • Can cause chronic diarrhoea in the immunocompromised host
  • Formation of sarcocysts within the muscle fibres (Muscular sarcocystosis)
  • Nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhoea (Intestinal sarcocystosis)

Microscopy

Oocyte is oval, acid-fast, 24-36 microns and autofluorescent, containing 8 sporozoites.

Oocyte is round, acid variable, 8-10 microns and autofluorescent, containing 2 - 2 sporozoites in each wheel.

Sarcocysts are present between the muscle fibres; each cyst has numerous merozoites.

questions.text: Identify the pathognomic structure given in the slide below
questions.explanation:
Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluoro cytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of diseases and their corresponding populations related to parvovirus is incorrect? 1. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease 2. Viral envelop - Naked virus 3. Erythema infectiosum - infants 4. Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:


 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: Which of the following is the false statement regarding statins?

options.label: A
options.text: Although HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events, there is a mild increase in lipoprotein a (Lpa) levels.

options.label: B
options.text: These drugs should not be stopped even in severe conditions like injury, surgery etc.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be given with verapamil and other enzyme inhibitors

options.label: D
options.text: With long-term use, there is a slight increase in the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.correct_answer: C. They can be given with verapamil and other enzyme inhibitors
questions.explanation:
Drugs

Mechanism of action

Statins / HMG CoA reductase inhibitors

  • Atorvastatin
  • Rosuvastatin
  • Simvastatin
  • Pitavastatin
  • Pravastatin

Inhibits HMG CoA reductase ➜ ￬cholesterol production in the liver (￬LDL cholesterol)

Fibrates / Activates PPAR-α

  • Gemfibrozil
  • Bezafibrate
  • Fenofibrate

Activates PPAR-α ➜ ￪expression of genes involved responsible for triglycerides breakdown and VLDL clearance.

Fibrates can ￬triglycerides and ￪HDL cholesterol levels.

Resins / Bile acid sequestrants

  • Cholestyramine
  • Colesevelam
  • Colestipol

Sequestrates bile acids (￬recycling of bile acids from the intestine to the liver) ➜ To compensate for this, the liver increases the conversion of cholesterol into bile acid ➜ ￬in hepatic cholesterol levels.

Lipolysis inhibitor/Triglyceride synthesis inhibitor

  • Niacin (Nicotinic acid)

Inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue ➜ ￬hepatic synthesis of VLDL and LDL ➜ ￬LDL cholesterol and triglycerides in blood.

Niacin also inhibits the breakdown of HDL ➜ ￪HDL levels.

Ezetimibe
  • Disrupts cholesterol and phytosterol absorption in small intestines via PCIL1 transporter protein interference.
  • Ezetimibe, with statins, enhances LDL-C reduction by inhibiting the rise of statin-induced cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg; HR, 72 beats/minute and respiratory rate, 32 breaths/ minute. He also complains of breathlessness. How do you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Prazosin

Drug class

Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker

MOA

Selectively blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

Indications
  • Hypertension
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Raynaud’s disease
  • Scorpion Bite (DOC)

Adverse effects
  • Postural hypotension
  • Retrograde ejaculation
  • Floppy iris syndrome
  • Reflex tachycardia occurs due to vasodilation.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected, and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature that led to the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Muscarinic poisoning

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

  • ➤ Reexamination after 24 hours is advisable as the bruises appear clearly by this time.

  • ➤ Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruises (six penny bruises from the force of fingertips).
  • ➤ Character and manner of injury

Mechanism of injury of contusions

  • A contusion or bruise is a leak of blood into the tissues due to the rupture of blood vessels (veins, venules, arterioles) caused due to injury by a blunt object.
  • Some blunt objects that can cause contusions are fist, stones, sticks, bar, whip, hammer, axe, wooden handle, poker, foot with shoe or boot, etc.

Factors influencing the formation of bruises

Condition and type of tissues
  • Vascular and loose tissues may form large bruises even with a small degree of violence.
    • Examples: face, vulva, and scrotum.
  • Firm fibrous tissues, strongly supported tissues, and those covered by a thick dermis produce a comparatively small bruise for moderate trauma.
    • Examples: abdomen, back, scalp, palms, and soles.
  • Injury of tissues over bony surfaces shows prominent bruising.

Age

  • Children bruise easily.
  • Older people bruise easily.

Gender

  • Women bruise more easily than men.
  • Obese people bruise easily due to the high volume of subcutaneous tissue.

Colour of the skin

  • Bruising is more easily visible in fair-skinned people than in dark-skinned people.
  • Contusions are better felt in dark-skinned people than seen.

Natural diseases

  • Prominent bruising is seen with minor trauma in patients with:
    • Arteriosclerosis
    • Whooping cough in children due to violent coughing can cause bruising
    • Purpura hemorrhagica
    • Leukemia
    • Hemophilia
    • Scurvy
    • Vitamin K
    • Prothrombin deficiency
    • Phosphorus poisoning
    • Older persons on systemic steroids

Gravity shifting of the blood

  • In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site.
  • This is called ectopic bruising or percolated or migratory contusion.
  • Examples:
    • Spectacle hematoma or black eye in blunt trauma to the forehead.
    • Bruise behind ear due to basal skull fracture (Battle’s sign).
    • Bruise in the neck from fracture of the jaw.
    • Bruise around the ankle from a kick on the calf.

G6PD (Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase) can manifest with which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
G6PD deficiency

Definition

It is an X-linked genetic disorder that impairs red blood cell protection against oxidative stress, leading to hemolytic anemia when exposed to certain triggers like medications, foods, or infections.

Etiology
  • G6PD catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone, generating NADPH.
  • NADPH is used to reduce oxidized glutathione (GSSG) to its active form (GSH), which neutralizes oxidative stress in RBCs.
  • Without G6PD, this protective mechanism is impaired, making RBCs more vulnerable to damage under oxidative stress

.

Triggers of Hemolysis

Drugs:

  • Antimalarials: Primaquine, chloroquine
  • Sulfonamides: Sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine
  • Antibiotics: Nitrofurantoin, dapsone
  • Analgesics: High-dose aspirin, phenacetin
  • Chemotherapeutics: Daunorubicin, doxorubicin
  • Others: Methylene blue, rasburicase, certain NSAIDs

Other Causes:

  • Fava beans (favism)
  • Infections: Certain viral and bacterial infections
  • Environmental Factors: Exposure to oxidizing agents, such as naphthalene

Pathogenesis

G6PD deficiency → Reduced glutathione levels decrease → Oxidative stress → Hemolysis → Acute hemolytic anemia

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sigmoid volvulus vs cecal volvulus | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org
  • ↳ Sigmoid Volvulus Imaging
  • ↳ Cecal Volvulus Imaging and Diagnosis: Practice Essentials, Radiography, Computed Tomography

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus
  • Sigmoid volvulus arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the right upper quadrant.
  • It has an ahaustral appearance (lack of haustra).
  • Causes obstruction of the distal large bowel, leading to dilation of the ascending, transverse, and descending colon.
  • A few gas-fluid levels may be seen.
  • Coffee-Bean Sign: The condition is characterized by a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, known as the coffee-bean sign (or kidney bean sign).
  • Whirlpool Sign: The whirl, or whirlpool sign is observed when the bowel rotates around its mesentery, resulting in whirls of the mesenteric vessels.
  • The torsion is located in the ascending colon above the ileocecal valve.
  • Caecal volvulus arises in the right lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the epigastrium or left upper quadrant.
  • The colonic haustral pattern is maintained.
  • The distal colon is usually collapsed, and the small bowel is distended.
  • One gas-fluid level may be seen.
  • Definitive Sign: Upward displacement of the appendix and obstruction of the large bowel is a definitive sign of cecal volvulus.
  • May show a U-shaped distended bowel segment and signs of ischemia, including mural thickening, infiltration of the mesenteric fat, and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • Whirlpool Sign: A whirl sign may be apparent due to tight torsion of the mesentery from a twist between the afferent and efferent loops.
  • Coffee Bean Appearance: A "coffee bean" appearance may be seen in a loop of transverse colon.
  • Bird's Beak Sign: Abrupt cut-off with “bird's beak” tapering at the distal cecum is characteristic.
  • Central appendix sign: Abnormal appendix position near midline.

questions.explanation:
Types of HPV
 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

HPV 16 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Oropharyngeal SCC

HPV 18 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Anogenital carcinoma

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts

  
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5, 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts

  
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions

  
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11).
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma, linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others.
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: Investigations of a patient being evaluated for leukaemia revealed a WBC count of 450,000/μL, with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

Category

Description

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22)

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene from t(9;22) increases tyrosine kinase activity, leading to uncontrolled myeloid proliferation. Radiation exposure is a risk factor.

Clinical Features
  • Affects adults.
  • Presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to blast crisis, resembling acute leukaemia.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm.
  • FISH detects the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

Bone Marrow aspirate findings.
  • Presence of scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm, called sea-blue histiocytes or pseudo-Gaucher cells.
  • The marrow is markedly hypercellular due to massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors (elevated eosinophils and basophils)
  • Increased megakaryocytes, commonly with small, dysplastic forms called dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Normal or slightly decreased erythroid progenitors (increased myeloid: erythroid ratio).
  • Increased deposition of reticulin fibres.

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) like Imatinib.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) (Option A):

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) (Option D):

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) (Option C):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent girl appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

A peripheral smear shows the presence of binucleated cells. Which of the following markers will be seen in this condition? CD15 CD30 CD19 CD3
questions.explanation:
Feature

Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL)

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

It is more common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localisation

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes.

Pattern of Spread

Orderly spread by contiguity.

Non Contiguous spread

Involvement of Mesenteric Nodes and Waldeyer Ring

Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved.

Waldeyer ring and mesenteric nodes are commonly involved.

Extranodal Presentation

Extranodal presentation is rare.

Extranodal presentation is common.

questions.text: Senile atrophy occurs due to which of the following?
Match the cytokines with the effector cells IL-4 Eosinophils IL-5 b. Mast cells IL-9 c. B cells IL-13 d. Dendritic cells
questions.explanation:
Cytokine

Effector Cell

IL-4

B cells

IL-5

Eosinophils

IL-9

Mast cells

IL-13

Dendritic cells

Interleukin (IL)

Function

IL-1

Promotes fever and inflammation and activates T cells and macrophages.

IL-2

Stimulates growth and activation of T cells, critical for adaptive immunity.

IL-3

Supports growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells (blood cell precursors).

IL-4

Stimulates B cell differentiation and promotes IgE production and Th2 response.

IL-5

Stimulates eosinophil differentiation and activation.

IL-6

Induces fever and acute-phase reactant production and supports B cell differentiation.

IL-7

Essential for T and B cell development and survival.

IL-8 (CXCL8)

Attracts neutrophils to sites of infection (chemotaxis).

IL-9

Promotes mast cell growth and regulates Th2 responses.

IL-10

Anti-inflammatory; inhibits Th1 responses and macrophage activity.

IL-12

Stimulates Th1 cell differentiation and enhances cytotoxic activity of T and NK cells.

IL-13

Modulates immune responses and activates macrophages.

IL-17

Promotes inflammation and recruitment of neutrophils, which are involved in autoimmunity.

IL-21

Stimulates B cell differentiation, plasma cell generation, and Th17 response.

IL-22

Induces antimicrobial peptide production and supports tissue repair.

IL-23

Promotes Th17 differentiation and inflammatory responses.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. identify the cause
questions.explanation:
Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A ruled out)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

RNA sequences

(Option B)

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA. (Option D ruled out)

Western blotting

(Option C ruled out)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

questions.text: During a routine eye examination, a patient's visual acuity was evaluated using Snellen's chart, and it was determined to be 6/6. What is the smallest angle at which this patient can differentiate two separate points or objects?
questions.explanation:
Snellen’s chart
  • Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points.
  • Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc.
 

Visual Acuity Notation
  • Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters).
  • Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision.
  • Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity.

Testing Procedure

The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter.

Limitations
  • Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses.
  • Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability.
  • Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision.
